awd_titl_txt: Transitivity of Sentences and Scenes in Early Language Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Children acquire their first language within a few years, and without explicit deliberation. Their task is extremely complex. They must come to perceive countless gestures or sounds as having the structure of sentences, with subjects, verbs, and so on. At the same time, they must come to understand how these sentences depict the world around them, as it is lived and portrayed by their caretakers and peers. How do they do this? Answering this question requires understanding how they experience both the language and the world around them, at each stage of their development. This research aims at one central part of the problem: how do infants learn the meanings of transitive verbs, those with a subject and object?  

This project approaches the problem from two directions. First, can children younger than 2 correctly perceive the category of 'transitive verb'? This may be difficult, because such verbs may occur in a variety of contexts that obscure their category, such as questions where the direct object occurs at the start of the sentence: "What did Mary see?" Second, how do children at this age tend to represent the events around them? Which aspects of an event are or are not salient to them? With some answers to both questions, the project moves on to asking what expectations children have about the connection between the syntax of transitive verbs and their meanings, expectations that might help them learn. This research will deepen our understanding of the relation between linguistic and nonlinguistic representations, and how these change in the early stages of language development.  Moreover, this work employs methods not previously used in research on the acquisition of syntax, expanding the range of methods available for others. Significant effort will also be directed towards outreach events in which graduate and undergraduate students working on the project will engage with high school and middle school students about the importance of linguistic research in general, and about the broader societal lessons that can be drawn from research on infant language learners.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the relation between linguistic structure and scene perception, probing phenomena revealing where the representation of event structure and sentence structure are not in perfect alignment. Sentence representations typically contain much less information than the thoughts they convey. Here we probed how children initially identify the alignment between conceptual representations of events and the sentences describing these events.

We first identified the number of participants in 10-month-olds' representations of specific events, finding (for example) that they represent a scene in which a woman takes a truck from a man as highlighting three participants (the woman, the man, and the truck). We then show that 20-month-olds allow such scenes to be described by sentences with only 2 Noun Phrases. This argues against the widespread view that participants in event representations and arguments sentence representations stand in a one-to-one relation. Instead, we find that young learners expect the subject of a sentence to name an agent and the object to name a patient, indepdnent of how many participants are in the event descxribed by that sentence.

We also demonstrated that 18-month-olds, but not younger children, represent wh-questions as involving a non-local dependency, This provides the first clear demonstration of non-local dependencies in infants' syntactic representations. We found, thought a listenting preference procedure, that 18-month-olds listen longer to sequences of grammatical sentences (such as, "the dog is hugging him" or "which cat is the dog hugging?") than they do to ungrammatical sequences (such as, "the dog is hugging" or "which cat is the dog hugging him?"). Younger infants, however, show listening preferences based on the local relation between the verb and the direct object, showing the same preference for Verb Noun-Phrase sequences independent of whether it is contained in a declarative sentence or wh-question.

Finally, we found that 20-month-olds treat object wh-questions containing novel verbs (what is she blicking?) as equivalent to transitive clauses (she's blicking it) for the purposes of verb learning. Infants look longer at scenes of a woman breaking a stick when they are described by intransitive clauses (she's blicking) than when they are described by transitive clauses or object wh-questions. This further supports the view that before their second birthday, infants represent sophisticated non-local dependency relations in syntax.

This project integrates theories of semantics and language acquisition, bridging communities of researchers who are too rarely in contact. Graduate students served as near-peer mentors to the undergraduate students, which provided them with mentoring experience, better prepared them for research positions, and provided a model for graduate training beyond individual research. Undergraduate students gained in-depth research experience and built their understanding of scientific reasoning and knowledge creation. Our project also had an outreach component, drawing on existing relations between our two departments, Linguistics and Philosophy, and local primary and secondary schools. In workshop meetings with students, our results informed a broader discussion of how the structure of sentences might relate to the structure of thoughts. This is a topic where philosophy, psychology and linguistics relate directly to classroom grammar, and can have a positive impact on the public understanding of language diversity. Finally, because the PIs are part of UMD's Infant and Child Studies Consortium, results were disseminated in nontechnical language to parents who participate in research at the university, broadening awareness of language and cognitive development.
